reviewText:
This is a terrible game, not even Pre-Alpha quality, filled with so many bugs it was PAINFUL to play the first hour I did.

- Game graphical bugs and glitches so apperent, they could have walked up and hit you with a stick.
- Music cuts out alot.
- The Objectives are so vegue, good luck finding anything for them.
- Spent the first 30min trying to get the second Objective to clear, due to I hadnt found a nessisary Trigger that was not even remotely needed to start the next objective.
- The fatigue and loosing consiousness mechanic is broken, and so fast that you have little time to get to be able to get your fatigue back up before you have to start all over.

Over all, this game is no where near 15$, I wouldnt have tried to finish this game if it were FREE

reviewText:
No...just no.  The poor optimization, not-so-fluid animations, and the constant crashing made me quit the game five minutes in.  When the developers decide to fix the game and make it playable, I'll be happy to revisit it.  For now, it's most certainly not worth $15.  Play the free game that came before this (One Late Night) on Desura instead.

http://www.desura.com/games/one-late-night

Edit: Gave the game another go after being informed of a patch.  The crashing as stopped and the average FPS went from 20-30 to 30-40, so the game has improved some.  I still find the animations to be a bit mechanical (not fluid or natural) and the headbobbing while running makes me extremely dizzy.  Both Amnesia and Outlast have better graphics, clock in at $20, and provide 4-8 hours of gameplay, so I'll hold off on further judgement as far as worth is concerned until I can determine how long this game actually is.

---

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bYATQoLfsm0

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rWNrfJZ0fp4

reviewText:
I'm going to summarize my time spent playing this game.

I started out in a rainstorm looking at the protagonist. The camera zoomed in and crashed into his head a la Goldeneye 64. After the AI walked into the building for me, I was in control. My objectives told me that I was to go to my office. I sprinted to the third floor. I say sprinted, but running in this game is the speed of slow walking and walking is the speed of an elderly person recovering from hip surgery.

Upon reaching my office, I picked up a paper from the desk and spent the next 5 minutes walking around the office trying to figure out how to fax it to the client. Eventually, I figured out that I wasn't standing in the exact place I needed to be while clicking the fax machine and it wasn't registering.

With that objective complete, I went to make some coffee. Coffee machines function as save points. However, in order to save, you must watch the coffee brew in real time. It's great standing in one spot for 30 seconds, unable to move, while a fresh, hot cuppa joe brews for you. As I was about to take a sip, I heard a scream from the second floor. What could be wrong?

I plodded to the second floor and stepped through a door, wandering the hall full of pitch dark offices, searching for what made the sound. Oh no! A spooky witch! Oh, it's gone. Back to walking. I'm getting tired. I'd better go drink some soda. Oh, the door is locked and I can't get back to the vending machines. I spent the next 10 minutes searching random desk drawers, each step slower than the last until I finally passed out from exhaustion and died. Fantastic.

Pros:
+ Nobody is forcing you to play this game.
+ Characters have noodle arms

Cons:
- Terrible framerate
- Mouse sensitivity is either way too high or way too low.
- Pop-in loading and invisible objects abound
- The worst lighting I have ever seen in any game
- Everything else

Avoid this game at all costs.

reviewText:
Black Curtain, what happened?

Honestly, I'm actually disappointed in you. One Late Night was amazing, I loved it, so when I heard they were making a sequel, I was really excited. Then one day I saw it had released and immediatly bought it.

But it wasn't what I expected.

Horrific frame rate, menus I couldn't close, unclear objectives, everything. I very rarely say this, but this game was bad. I tried to be optimistic, but the game is so broken I just couldn't deny the truth. This game would not, and could not, live up to the predecessors potential.

If you do read this, Black Curtain, I do have something good to say. The voice acting and story (as much of it as I could find) was great, so why did you focus on story only? This would have been better as a book, because books don't glitch out or skip load times into a level you already passed. Maybe if you remake the actual gameplay, so that it's functional, I would consider playing this game again, but for now, this is quite literally the worst game i've ever played. WORSE than Ride to Hell: Retrebution or Air Control, because those game are hilariously bad. This is just...

Depressingly bad. You screwed One Late Night up.

reviewText:
Black Curtain Studio has a lot to learn. I studied Game Development and during my time as student, I have seen first year students create better game prototypes within 6 months (some of them even in Unity) then BCS did here. So the “small team/no budget” card is no excuse for me.

One Late Night Deadline ask for nearly as much as Outlast, which is an indie title developed by AAA veterans who are able to deliver a certain quality level. Even if BCS would have managed an at least bug free, stable FPS version of One Late Night, the overall quality would not even be near to a title like Outlast (with production costs of 1,4 millions of dollar).

As already mentioned, the FPS is a clear no go in this game. Even on lowest settings the game does not run smooth, but this was already mentioned over and over.

What is another major killer for me in this game, is the whole game design. I have played the free prequel which had some issues as well, but at least it was able to transport an interesting and scary atmosphere. Just to boost things up and create a bigger environment does not create a better overall experience. Most of the time, I really had no idea what to do, and if I knew, what, I did not know why".  I would recommend the developer to study some game designing techniques first and get a good grasp of how to create a more enjoyable experience for the player before asking for money.
Most people like indie games for their brave and unusual ideas and mechanics
date: but One Late Night Deadline does not offer any of this. The whole project was set up far to big and ambitious without the knowledge of even the most important basics in nearly all areas.\n\nIf Black Curtain studio would have invested their time to take the prequel game and polished it’s content and features and then sell this version for around 5 to 10 dollars
hoursPlayed: they would have been able to create a very fine and enjoyable game.\n"
voteText: March 12, 2015

reviewText:
I want to say at front that I don't recomend bying this right now due to the framerate issues people seem to be having, but I recomend to wait for a while for a patch if it is patchable.

Now that  that's out of the way I still enjoy it. I haven't gotten yet to the scary elements of the game other then one scream from a woman but the office building sets up the chilling mood and a believable enviroment for the story to take place upon.

I managed to encounter some minor bugs aswell that while not game breaking can break the immersion a bit:
Clipping issues when using the soda/coffee machine, some animations a bit off (pressing buttons that aren't there, might be because of the low graphics that I had to run to play the game on a reasonable fps) and the lift leaving me to the top of    the elevator shaft.

Still the mystery of the game intrigues me a lot and with some small polish to the game, it would rate very well on my books.

reviewText:
ok, barely played it.

BUT!

No one has written a review since the january patches and I feel this guy deserves some credit.

Sure, there are some weak animations, and it's a little buggy, but I found it runs nicely on my GTX750 (framerates are good on Nice setting, in my opinion the game feels smoother with the mouse sensitivity turned down, but maybe that's just me). The head bob is annoying but it's only when you run.

All the really bad stuff has been fixed. I gave up on this game multiple times within minutes and now i'm looking forward to getting some more time in with it. It's running rather nicely.

Now, it's not fair comparing this to amnesia or outlast as this is a one man show HOWEVER I can understand since it is priced rather high for what you're getting.

If, on the other hand, you've played the first one, you like it, you're not too stingy with your money and like a good horror game (cuz we all know how many bad ones there are) So far this is not a bad game at all.

I recommend it with reservations, but I also am very pleased with how much work the developer has put into fixing these issues.

reviewText:
Warning: Spoilers Ahead!

Hello. First, I would like to point out that I originally gave this game a positive review because I thought several graphical issues like low FPS would be fixed in update 1.1. However, this does not appear to be the case. While many things were changed in update 1.1, there are still several issues with this, like being able to fix the vending machine BEFORE you find the phone (which, there is no objective as far as I know to getting the phone before you go to the room in which it is in, so it is already hard to find), which completely messes up the storyline and what the heck you are doing. Also, I am almost certain I save in a certain spot, and it takes me all the way back to where you first get coffee on the third floor. (Though I could be wrong.) However, that being said, 1.1 also brought many new elements to the game, like the scary man appearing in new places. However, the lady constantly appears in the office when I try to use the fax machine, which can get annoying. All in all, the game is NOT bad. However, it needs to have several things be fixed and tweaked, along with the graphics issues fixed. Until then, I would wait for this game to be fixed.

This next section only applies to the people who are giving this game lots of hate.

While I am dissapointed with this game in several ways, I am also dissapointed to the way people have reviewed this game. For example, reviews such as: Just Nasty!" (Yes
date: that is a quote.) are offensive to the developer of this game. Yes
recommended: while he does need to work on several things on the game
hoursPlayed: it doesn't give anyone the right to be rude about it. (To be honest
voteText: the "Funny" review function on Steam was a mistake.)"

reviewText: In technical terms this game is almost completely unplayable: I've experienced numerous bugs, crashes, problems with saving and loading game, dreadful characters animation and music issues. Vague game goals make this torture even more unbearable. Another nice story that was completely ruined by the lack of developer's skills.

reviewText: This game is very laggy on my HP 2000 PC. I spent $10 on this game. I have other games on my computer that run nice and smooth, but this is the only game I have that does not. This game is unplayable for me. When I walk forward, it takes 5 seconds for the game to do that. I wasted $10 on this laggy game. I would definitely like my money back.
